titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the James Weldon Johnson Collection Manuscript Miscellany
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke Staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Wednesday April 24, 2019 at 03:22

did.unittitle: James Weldon Johnson Collection manuscript miscellany

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Single manuscripts and small groups of manuscripts, including literary manuscripts, letters, and other documents. Materials are grouped under headings by author or corporate name.
did.physdesc: Other Storage Formats: oversize, bound volumes

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: James Weldon Johnson Memorial Collection of Negro Arts and Letters (Yale University)

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Ongoing collection of documents acquired by gift and purchase from various sources. Source information is recorded on each folder. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The James Weldon Johnson Collection Manuscript Miscellany is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Author], [Item Title]. James Weldon Johnson Collection Manuscript Miscellany. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research. Restricted Fragile Papers may only be consulted with permission of the appropriate curator. Preservation photocopies for reference use have been substituted in the main files.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This finding aid is updated periodically to account for new materials that have been added to the Miscellany. The date of the most recent update is noted on the title page. For information on material that may have been incorporated into the Miscellany since the last update, please consult the Public Service Desk.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This finding aid encompasses single manuscripts and small groups of manuscripts acquired by the Beinecke Library from various sources and at various times, which the Library has chosen to describe here rather than as separate entries in Yale University Library's on-line Public Access Catalog (Orbis). These materials include literary manuscripts, individual or small groups of letters, and single documents. Materials are grouped under headings for author or other personal or corporate name to which they most closely relate. Items of unidentified authorship are grouped separately under "Unidentified" at the end of the finding aid. Group numbers were assigned as items were added to the collection; entries appear in alphabetical order by main entry, not in group number order. Within each group, folders (F-[#]) and volumes (V-[#]) are numbered in order of processing.

To request materials listed here, please cite the Miscellany call number, written as JWJ MSS MISC, the group number, and the folder or volume number appearing to the left of the item description. For example, to obtain item F-1 from the materials listed under J. California Cooper, complete an individual call slip as follows:
JWJ MSS MISC
Grp 1, Item F-1

This list is ongoing, and it is subject to revision as new materials are acquired and, on occasion, as groups of manuscripts are removed and cataloged separately as artificial collections. When materials are removed and reclassified, a cross reference to the new call number is placed in the list.

In addition to newly received items which have been described using current cataloging standards, this finding aid contains previoulsy cataloged material. Descriptions for the latter items have been transcribed from card sets in the Manuscript Catalog; these entries are identified by "rec," followed by the year of the conversion, e.g., (rec/97).

controlaccess.subject: African American authors
American literature
Authors, American
controlaccess.corpname: James Weldon Johnson Memorial Collection of Negro Arts and Letters (Yale University)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Essay, holograph, on Edmund Wilson, signed at Nice. With typed transcript.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Draft, typescript mimeograph, of Baldwin's screenplay based on Alex Haley's The Autobiography of Malcolm X. Differs substantially from version published in 1973 as One Day, When I Was Lost; possibly an earlier draft.
Inscribed "Background material for screenplay on Malcolm X. Calder Willingham."

did.unittitle: "Notes for Project : Letter to My Younger Brother"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Manuscript, typed and signed, discussing a book project.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Draft, typescript, of article for The Reporter. Accompanied by three TLS, dating from 1952, to "Mr. Rodman" of The Reporter, all regarding the article, and one ANS to an unidentified recipient.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One TLS in which Baldwin announces his intention to finish "Letter for My Younger Brother," describes his thoughts on newly begun novel ("Giovanni's Room"), and requests a loan of twenty dollars. The letter includes a clipping of an article on James Baldwin from the Herald Tribune Book Review (1953 May 31).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One TLS to Samuel L. Blumenfeld written in Paris roughly one month after Baldwin's first book was published.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One TLS to Samuel L. Blumenfeld, written in Cannes, discussing various writing projects, including Baldwin's new work on a "primer" based on correspondence with his younger brother, completion of "The Amen Corner," and work towards his second novel, Giovanni's Room.

did.unittitle: Letters : between Sam[uel L. Blumenfeld] and Baldwin

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One TLS to Samuel L. Blumenfeld, written in Corsica, and one TL to Baldwin from Blumenfeld. Baldwin mentions a new novel (possibly "Another Country"), the reception of "Giovanni's Room," and discusses returning to New York in the Spring of 1957. In his letter Blumenfeld discusses reading "Giovanni's Room" and compliments Baldwin's writing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One ALS and two TLS to Edward Parone. Baldwin discusses his play "The Amen Corner"as well as his personal life (such as his financial situation and partner Lucien Happersberger). Includes letter written while Baldwin was at Yaddo and in New York and Washington, D.C.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence regarding a proposed stage adaptation of Baldwin's novel, Giovanni's Room (New York: Dial Press, 1956). Correspondence includes one typescript letter, signed, from Baldwin to Wilson, and one typescript carbon letter from Wilson to Baldwin. Accompanied by 15 letters between between Wilson and others, including Albert I. Da Silva of Reinheimer & Cohen, Frederick L. Keefe of The New Yorker , and representatives of the William Morris Agency.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from William Reese Co. (Swann Galleries sale, New York, 2009 February 26, lot 257) on the James Weldon Johnson Memorial Collection of Negro Arts & Letters Fund, 2009

did.unittitle: Letters : to Shawn Henderson, 1977 Park Blvd., Camden, New Jersey 08103

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, with accompanying envelopes, includes three autograph letters, signed, two autograph notes, signed, and one page with notes and sketches. Letters discuss writing, books, travel, and other engagements.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from William Reese Co. (Swann sale 2342, New York, 2014 March 27, lot 341) on the American Literature Fund, 2014

did.unittitle: "An Open Letter to My Sister, Angela Y. Davis"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Draft, typescript, corrected, of essay. Differs from version published in The New York Review of Books (January 7, 1971 issue). Signed "Brother James".

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Elysium Press on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund, 2015.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Between the Covers on the Donald Windham-Sandy Campbell Collection Endowment Fund, 2011.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Drafts, typescript, corrected, signed and dated 1995 (16 l.), and photocopy of typescript, corrected, signed and dated July 30, 1969 (18 l.).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Draft, typescript mimeograph, corrected, of Berg's screenplay for the film Honky . "Shelia" was the working title and source novel title.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Royal Books on The Bradford F. and Lila L. Swan Fund, 2016.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One TLS regarding Tenth Birthday Party for the Poets and Writers organization.
Removed from Poets & Writers, Inc.: Tenth Birthday Party. New York: Poets & Writers, Inc., 1980.

did.unittitle: Letter : Cambridge, Massachusetts, to Robert Underwood Johnson, New York, New York

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed, regarding submission of verses for The Century Magazine, and the death of Richard Watson Gilder.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Removed from the Carl Van Vechten Papers, 2017.

did.unittitle: Photographs of African-American men and women by J. Brasel, Muskogee, Indian Territory

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Six carte de visite size photographs of young African- American men and women. Three show women, and three show men; two are bust portraits, while four are full-length portraits with studio props. Probably photographed in the 1870s-80s.

did.unittitle: Letters and inscriptions : to James E. Kelly

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: ANS in holiday card thanking Kelly for sharing the "Sheltered Man," in enveloped postmarked 1985 Dec 16; ALS dated 1986 Jan 4, regarding Kelly's artwork; a printed 1979 Chicago Public Library bookmark containing "To Young Readers," a poem by Brooks, inscribed to Kelly and signed by Brooks; and an undated card inscribed to Kelly and signed by Brooks.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Poem, four lines, holograph, signed, with 'From "Bronzeville Boys and Girls"' written by Brooks on verso.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two ALS and an annotated typescript of a syllabus for the "Chicago Teachers College North Poetry Workshop."

did.unittitle: Review of "Collected Poems of Langston Hughes."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph manuscript of Brooks' review of "Collected Poems of Langston Hughes" edited by Arnold Rampersad. Brooks provides an overview of the collection and then critiques particular poems. The manuscript is accompanied by a copy of Brooks' letter to the editor regarding the review.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph manuscript of a title page and drafts of three poems for Children Coming Home: "Superbe/A Something of My Own," "God is a White Gorilla," and "Richardine: White Girls are Particular People." The manuscript also includes a table of contents for In Montgomery and Other Poems. The manuscript is titled Blacks volume II.

did.unittitle: Photograph of Gwendolyn Brooks at the 1973 Fourth Annual Illinois Poet Laureate Awards

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Gelatin silver black and white photographic print [by Frank Giamboy?] of Gwendolyn Brooks at the Fourth Annual Illinois Poet Laureate Awards held at the University of Chicago in 1973 in Chicago, Illinois. Brooks is shown reading a copy of MAJI: A Journal of the Black Arts, the quarterly publication of MAJI-MAJI Collective at Temple University in Philadelphia, while an unidentified African American man looks on. Also pictured are three other unidentified individuals.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Waiting for Godot Books on the James Weldon Johnson Memorial Collection of Negro Arts & Letters Fund, 2009.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typescript draft of article written for Interracial Review

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Dorothy Peterson through Carl Van Vechten, 1953

did.unittitle: Letter : The Tuskegee Normal and Industrial Institute, to Ms. Rebecca Caudill

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from James Cummins Bookseller on the George B. Alvord Fund, 2011.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One ALS (December 6, 1926), with TLCS enclosed, comprised of responses to three questions: 1. Does truth exist only in the abstract?; 2. What is necessary to have a knowledge of things, as you spoke of in your informal talk?; 3. Do you believe that God, Truth, beauty, music, nature and science are interchangeable terms, and a worship -- worship in the sense of study and self devotion -- of any particular one of these, is equivalent to a worship of any one of the others?. Accompanied by original envelope (postmarked January 13, 1927).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Short story, holograph, written on the verso of Chestnutt's Cleveland, Ohio stenographer business paper. With ALS dated 1942 Jul 22, from Chestnutt's daughter, Helen M. Chestnutt, Cleveland, Ohio, to Harold Jackman, New York, and ALS dated 1942 Aug 3 to Carl Van Vechten, New York, both regarding the short story.

did.unittitle: "The Liberty Monument (in memory of the patriots who fell in the riot of September 14, 1874)"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Essay, typescript with holograph corrections and additions, and a photocopy of the typescript, with holograph corrections and additions. With a manuscript draft of an announcement regarding publications of the Archives of Negro History in an unidentified hand.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Draft, typescript mimeograph, of Coleman's script for the unproduced play. Laid in is a typed letter, signed, by Coleman addressed to "Frank" stating that a mutual friend, "Ralph", considers the play to be good for production, dated 1965 September 9.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Royal Books on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund, 2015.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Composite script complete, typescript mimeograph, corrected, of Marc Connelly and Joseph Schrank's screenplay for the film Cabin in the Sky .

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Royal Books on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund, 2016.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: TLS, regarding Cooper's work. With blank envelope.

did.unittitle: Letter : to Charles Van Natten, Tarrytown, New York

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One ALS enclosing a ticket to J.P. Stenson's Mammoth Pavilion "Uncle Tom's Cabin Co." Drawing of "Uncle Tom" on the envelope.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Poem, autograph manuscript, signed.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Between the Covers on the George B. Alvord Fund, 2016.

did.unittitle: Letter : to Thomas Secondo, Enfield, CT

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: TLS responding to Mr. Secondo's inquiry about Forrest Bartley Whittaker, Jr., who played basketball for Dartmouth in 1926. Accompanied by: a copy of Whittaker's matriculation card; a copy of a 1953 letter from Dartmouth's alumni office to the Registrar of Vital Statistics in Columbus, Ohio, with reply; copies of pages from the athletics section of the Dartmouth Alumni Magazine, 1926, which mention Whittaker; a carbon copy of Secondo's letter of inquiry to Dartmouth, 1991 June 11; and a copy of The Dartmouth Pictorial, Carnival Number, 1926, which includes a photo of Whittaker.
Removed from the Randolph Linsly Simpson African-American Collection.

did.unittitle: Papers relating to The Confession Stone: Song Cycles

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Forty-nine-page typescript mimeograph copy of "The Confession Stone: Song Cycles," with annotations and corrections in pencil and pen in an unidentified hand, "copyrighted 1965," and bound in a white folder containing manuscript notes in an unidentified hand on the inside back cover; eleven-page typescript carbon of "The Land of the Living and The Land of the Risen Dead," dated 1962 Nov 16; "Mary's Lullaby" printed on a leaf followed by Dodson's reproduced signature and "Christmas, 1963"; oversized picture postcard containing a portrait photograph of Countee Cullen with a note dated 1970 Apr 30 from Dodson to Paul Breman regarding Confession Stone on the verso; typed coctail party invitation to Paul Breman dated 1976 Dec 15, from Dodson and his wife Edith, mimeographed on the verso of a printed holiday card containing the poem "A Certain Glory"; portrait photograph of Dodson by Kurt Ammann; and six undated 9 x 5 cm. cards containing holograph notes for an unidentified lecture.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Poem, typescript, signed.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Dorothy Burnham, 2014.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One TLS and one TPcS regarding a presentation copy of Dove's Ten poems.
Removed from Ten poems (Lisbon: Penumbra Press, 1977).

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from the William Reese Company on the James Weldon Johnson Memorial Collection of Negro Arts & Letters Fund, 2012.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: From the collection of Marjorie Wiggin Prescott.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sonnet, autograph manuscript, signed, printers' copy. Published in Century Magazine (November 1898).

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from William Reese Company on the James Weldon Johnson Memorial Collection of Negro Arts & Letters Fund, 2009.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Poem, draft, autograph manuscript, corrected, signed "P.L.D." Published in The Saturday Evening Post (1901).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Draft, typescript mimeograph, corrected, of Berg's screenplay for the film Home of the Brave . "High Noon" was the working title. Thirteen 8 x 10 photographs from the film are bound-in.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Walter Reuben, Inc. on the Sinclair Lewis Fund, 2015.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Printed program for 16th annual festival honoring James Baldwin and John O. Killens.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Heritage Book Shop, Inc. on the James Weldon Johnson Memorial Collection of Negro Arts & Letters Fund, 2001
Removed from Fifth Sunday (Lexington: University of Kentucky, 1985) by Rita Dove.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Draft, typescript mimeograph, corrected, of Frost and Wes Bishop's screenplay for the film The Thing with Two Heads . "The Man with Two Heads" was the working title. The copy likely belonged to Roosevelt "Rosey" Grier, whose name is written on the front wrapper.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Royal Books on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund, 2015.

did.unittitle: Letter : New York, to Hall Johnson

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: ALS regarding "Run, Little Chillun."

did.unittitle: Letter : Johannesburg, South Africa, to William Johnston

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: TLS regarding The Classic Johannesburg Quarterly, a literary magazine for which Gordimer served as a trustee. With a printed subscription form and a typed description of the publication.

did.unittitle: H. M. VELIE'S COLORED SONG BIRDS AND CONCERT CO.

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: H. M. Velie's Colored Song Birds and Concert Co.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials include a broadside for a 1896 tour and hotel and theater contracts, completed in manuscript.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Holograph manuscript draft of article, corrected, for T.V. Guide on "Roots" program. Accompanied by clipping of cover, signed, for October 1976 issue of the Journal of the Film and Television Arts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Libretto, mimeograph typescript, with cover containing the label of the Rialto Mimeographing and Typing Service Bureau, New York.

did.unittitle: Letter : New York, to Rodney A. Coleman

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: TLS which accompanied material that Handy autographed for Coleman. Accompanied by a sheet on which is affixed a photograph of Handy clipped from an unidentified publication, four W. C. Handy commemorative postage stamps, and an envelope postmarked Tuskegee Institute, Alabama, with a first day issue Booker T. Washington postage stamp; a signature of Handy cut from an unidentified document is glued to the front of the envelope.

did.unittitle: Letter : San Francisco, California, to Lewis M. Isaacs, Jr.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: ALS regarding the Theatre Arts Project for East Harlem in honor of Edith J. R. Isaacs. With a printed brochure describing the Project.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Manuscript, typescript, corrected, on the origin of Christmas.

did.physdesc: 1 item (37 p.) ; 28 cm., in paper cover, 29 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Script, typescript mimeograph, including both "Mister Jazz" and "Shakespeare in Harlem," the latter adapted by Robert Glenn and with background music by Margaret Bonds; with original typist's cover.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Empty envelope sent from Rmulo Lachataer to Hughes.
Removed from: Rmulo Lachataer's "!!Oh, mio Yemaya!!" (Manzanillo, Cuba : Editorial "El Arte", 1938).

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Waiting for Godot Books on the Danford N. Barney, Jr. Fund, 2012.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One TLS sent on behalf of Hughes by his secretary, Adele M. Glasgow, to Vernon Reyman thanking Reyman for his letter to Hughes and suggesting Reyman obtain a copy of Hughes' I Wonder as I Wander from Rinehart and Company. Accompanied by an envelope.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Doris Griss on the Carl Van Vechten Fund, 2012.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph manuscript, with partial lyrics for "Crazy Hat," on Hotel Times Square stationary (undated). Four TLS (1945-1946), 1 postcard, signed (1946), from Langston Hughes to Harry Belkin regarding the song. Two TLS from the Library of Congress Copyright Office (1945 October) confirming copyright.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed, possibly to Harry Block, an editor at Alfred A. Knopf, Inc. The letter discusses public events, including readings, and critical response to an unidentified book, most likely The Weary Blues (New York: Knopf, 1926). The letter also mentions [Mary White] Ovington, [W.C.] Handy, and [Witter] Bynner, among others.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Schulson Autographs on the Sinclair Lewis Fund, 2016

did.unittitle: Letter : Great Barrington, Mass., to Marshall Best

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Glenn Horowitz Bookseller, 2011.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One ALS, with envelope, sent to Marshall Best in which Grace Nail Johnson proposes turning the garage of Five Acres, the Johnsons' home, into a memorial for James Weldon Johnson. The letter is accompanied by three photographs of the property and a note "Suggestions for converting garage at Five Acres," outlining thirteen building projects.

did.unittitle: Letters : Great Barrington, Mass., to Rosemary Farrar

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two ALS, dated Sep 19, 1935, and Aug 31, 1937, with envelope. The letters praise Farrar's poetry and briefly discuss poems sent by her to Johnson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 1 necktie belonging to James Weldon Johnson given by Ollie Jewel Sims Okala to Stephen Jones, of the Beinecke Library, in gratitude for his work on the James Weldon Johnson Memorial Collection. Necktie is from Steffin (510 Madison Avenue) with a design of red and white feathers on a black background.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Stephen Jones, 2014.

did.unittitle: Letters : Great Barrington, Mass., and New York, N.Y., to George Oppenheimer

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two ALS, dated Sep 26, 1928, and Aug 26th, n.y., with article "Books for Porch Reading" from Better Homes and Gardens (1928 July) enclosed. One TLS, dated May 18, 1927. Letters concern Johnson's book God's Trombones .

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Glenn Horowitz Bookseller on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund, 2011.

did.unittitle: Letters : between James Weldon Johnson and Harold Guinzburg

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two ALS to Harold Guinzburg, one TLS and 1 TL from Harold Guinzburg. One TL to from Guinzburg, dated Aug. 13, 1925, concerning Johnson's contribution to "The Subway Sun," an ad campaign sponsored by the New York subway system, with two ALS, dated Aug. 21 and 26, 1925, with Johnson's reply. The second ALS includes Johnson's blurb for the campaign: "I ride on the subway because it enables me to spend 15 minutes longer over my breakfast table uptown and 15 minutes longer at my desk downtown, without being late going or coming."
One TLS from Guinzburg, dated Aug. 26, 1926, includes an AL from Johnson at the bottom, concerning dedication of God's Trombones .

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Glenn Horowitz Bookseller on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund, 2011.

did.unittitle: Letters : Great Barrington, Mass. and Fisk University, Nashville, Tenn., to Marshall Best

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Glenn Horowitz Bookseller on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund, 2011.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Three TLS and 1 ALS to Marshall Best. TLS, dated July 4, 1930, regarding Saint Peter Relates and Incident and Fifty Years and Other Poems . TLS, dated April 12, 1934, concerns The Oppermanns by Lion Feuchtwanger. In his TLS, dated July 18, 1934, Johnson thanks Best for a copy of the play "Stevedore" and asks Best to sell his article provisionally titled "Interracialism, A Requisite of World Peace" (based on his address 'The Art of Being Civilized") to Harper's . ALS, dated December 10, 1937, in which Johnson plans on stopping by Best's office in order to play a recorded recitation of his poem "The Crucifixion," from God's Trombones , made "by the lady in Atlanta."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Draft, typescript, corrected, for long poem on ruins of Vesuvius, Herculaneum, and Pompeii. Dedicated: "for Millen and for Julius and for Eddie." Inscribed: "for Clarence and Sharyn, [Major} Life! June."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Revised draft, typescript mimeograph, of Julien, Bill Tennant, and Sheldon Keller's screenplay for the film Cleopatra Jones .

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Royal Books on the The Bradford F. and Lila L. Swan Fund, 2016.

did.unittitle: Photograph of Ted Joans and Bob Kaufman

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Informal bust-length portrait showing the poets smiling broadly; Kaufman has his arm around Joans's shoulders, and Joans holds a bottle of Guinness stout.

did.unittitle: "Prospectus of the Present and Proposed Collections of Negro Americana, Africana, and Documents Relating to the Negro"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typescript accompanied by two memorandum "Re: The Study of Race Literature, History, and Origins," typescripts, signed, regarding the creation of a collection at Howard University library focusing on Negro-Americana. One TLS and one TL to the President and Board of Trustees, Howard University, "Re: Negro-Americana" (February 3, 1913 and May 6, 1915), in which Locke outlines five recommendations, such as establishing a curatorship of Negro-Americana and appointing an editor of Negro-Americana. One TLS to Jesse Edward Moorland (May 20, 1915) requesting feedback on the prospectus.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Swann Auction Galleries on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund, 2012.

did.unittitle: "Lady Sings the Blues: The Billie Holiday Story"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Second draft, typescript mimeograph, corrected, of McCloy's screenplay for the film Lady Sings the Blues: The Billie Holiday Story . Laid in: typed letter, signed, to Leonard Lighstone from Stevie Phillips, with plot summary and reader criticism, dated 1970 January 26.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Royal Books on The Bradford F. and Lila L. Swan Fund, 2016.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One TLS in which McKay asks Spingarn if he could get him a job with the United States Office of War Information (which at that time was directed by Elmer Davis).

did.unittitle: Letter : to Mrs. Willie M. Shaw
did.physdesc: 1 item (written on a clipping) ; 58 cm., folded to 29 cm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Brief ALS to Mrs. Willie M. Shaw, mother of James E. Shaw, regarding family news. The letter is written on a newspaper clipping of an article about McWilliams, her family, and her work as a music teacher, "Ruth McWilliams -- And Her Exceptional Way," Palo Verde Valley Times, Aug 10, 1967. Accompanied by an undated AN written by James E. Shaw, about the letter, and an envelope.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One APcS to Mrs. T.J. Murphy and 1 publisher's advertisement.
Removed from: Dunbar, Paul Laurence. Complete Poems. New York: Dodd, Mead and Co., 1913.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fourth revised draft, typescript mimeograph, of Nash's screenplay for the film Porgy and Bess .

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Royal Books on the Adele Gutman Nathan Theatrical Collection Fund, 2016.

did.unittitle: Letters : to Tom and Sylvia Paquette

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Eight ALS, three TLS, five ANS, and two holograph postcards, signed, with 15 envelopes, briefly discussing her writing and speaking engagements, other travel, and personal news. Also present are photocopies of four articles written by Naylor for the New York Times, with an envelope addressed to Sylvia Paquette.

did.unittitle: "To Be Young, Gifted, and Black: The World of Lorraine Hansberry in Her Own Words / adapted by Robert Nemiroff"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Playscript, actor's copy, typescript mimeograph. The script is annotated in manuscript, possibly by Sharon Shayne, who used the script while an understudy for a Broadway production.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Waiting for Godot Books on the Martin Greenblatt Foundation Book Fund in American Literature, 2011.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One TLS, dated February 1, 1915, from A. Bray, Treasurer of the Palmer Memorial Institute, to Helen F. Kimball, founder of the Sedalia Club of Brookline, Mass., which raised funds for the Palmer Memorial Institute. Six autograph postcards, signed (1914-1916), sent to Marian D. Richards, regarding the Sedalia Club. Printed ephemera, constituting promotional material for the Palmer Memorial Institute, include a brochure, "What Others Say of the Palmer Memorial Institute" (undated), a broadside reproducing a panoramic photograph of the institute's grounds (1913), and a postcard with a group portrait of the institute's faculty and students (undated).

did.unittitle: Letter : 1501 Blake St., No. 317, Berkeley, CA 94703, to Peter Howard, 654 Colusa Avenue, Berkeley, CA 94707

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One autograph letter, signed, on printed card, folded and with envelope. The letter discusses Howard's support, the Serendipity edition of Nigga in the Woodpile (2008), and Howard's bookstore, Serendipity Books, and mentions Annie Barrows, Andrew Hoyem, and others.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Peter Howard, 2010

did.unittitle: Correspondence with Victor Gollancz concerning Paul Robeson, Negro and African Journey

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from R. A. Gekoski on the George B. Alvord Fund, 2014.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 7 ALS and 3 TLS to Gollancz and 12 carbon TL to Robeson, dating from 1929 to 1930, concerning Paul Robeson, Negro (New York; London: Harper, 1930). 1 TLS, dated December 3, 1945, to Gollancz regarding African Journey (New York: John Day Co., 1945). Accompanied by original contracts, signed, reader's report, and third-party correspondence pertaining to royalties, permissions, and other legal matters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Final draft, typescript mimeograph, of Schumacher's screenplay for the film D.C. Cab . "Capitol Cab" was the working title.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Royal Books on the The Bradford F. and Lila L. Swan Fund, 2016.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: TLS to Dwight Macdonald, 1958 Dec 30, discussing his hopes of money for work sent to Ginsburg and Hess and enclosing a poem, "Sterne," for Gloria Macdonald; APcS to Dwight Macdonald, 1938 Jun 29, from Bennington, Vermont, inviting him to stay; two-line poem on the back of an envelope for the Macdonalds, 1958 Aug; envelope addressed to Miss Hettie Cohen, 1959 Mar 4; manuscript notes on "Having Snow"; manuscript poem, "March 29, I"; and typescript poem, "Poem," beginning "The winter sky, leaden, whitened and brightened a little," with holograph first line inserted, "You are what you want to be [...]"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Draft, typescript mimeograph, of Silliphant's screenplay for the film.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Royal Books on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund, 2015.

did.unittitle: Photograph of Nina Simone performing at the Newport Jazz Festival

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Gelatin silver black and white photographic print, by Berlin photographer Ursula Rhnert, of American singer, songwriter, and musician Nina Simone performing on stage at the 1967 Newport Jazz Festival. Simone is shown mid-performance holding a microphone and wearing a white, crocheted, open fishnet outfit.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Royal Books on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund, 2019.

did.unittitle: "Are We Solving Our Race Problem? -- Some Functioning Programs"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typescript list, briefly discussing ways of fighting racism. Annotated "Smythe's notes for Boston, Dec. 8, 1946," in manuscript in an unidentified hand.
Removed from his Negro Masses and Leaders: An Analysis of Current Trends ([1950?]).

did.unittitle: "Amiri Baraka/LeRoi Jones: The Quest for a 'Populist Modernism'"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Literary biography, incomplete draft, photocopy of a typescript, with corrections written by Baraka in holograph.

did.unittitle: Letter : to [W. E. B.] Du Bois

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Draft of an autograph letter, corrected and initialed, concerning an event that evening and distribution of prizes relating to Amy Spingarn or The Crisis , the NAACP's monthly magazine edited by Du Bois.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Stuart Lutz Historic Documents, Inc. on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund, 2016

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Draft, typescript, corrected and annotated, for a three-act play about a black family living in Harlem during the Great Depression.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autobiography, typescript, carbon. Annotated in manuscript: "Confidential" and "Mr. Eliot" [i.e. T. S. Eliot], possibly in the hand of Tutuola.
Removed from his The Palm-Wine Drinkard and His Dead Palm-Wine Tapster in the Dead's Town (London: Faber and Faber, [1952]).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Postcard, addressed in manuscript in an unidentified hand to Twomey in Danielson, Connecticut, and annotated "In remembeance [sic] of James C. Burley, Hampton Institute, Hampton, Va." On the postcard is a printed photograph of the "Battalion of Cadets, Hampton Institute, Virginia."

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Glenn Horowitz Bookseller on the George B. Alvord Fund, 2012.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Drafts, typescripts, corrected. Possibly written for the first convention of the Young Workers League of America (held in Brooklyn, May 13-15, 1922).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph manuscript notebook with the following fables: "A Leopard and Kbagna," "The Disobedient Boy," "The Hunter and the Gazelle," "The Story of the Juwa," and "On the Origin of the Difference Between the Black and White Races."

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Waiting for Godot Books on the Martin Greenblatt Foundation Book Fund in American Literature, 2011.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from the William Reese Company on the George B. Alvord Fund, 2012.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph manuscript of eight anti-slavery poems. The first line for the first poem reads: "Oh give me a republic where the boast of Freedom rings. / Where white men are all citizens, the colored only things, / Where the government refuses a Government to own / Not on the ground of principles, but that of skins alone."

did.unittitle: Tintype copy photograph of a drawing of an unidentified man

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Full-plate tintype copy photograph with heavy multicolored overpainting of a seated man in a dark suit. The tintype was likely produced from a drawing or painting of an unidentified man. Tintype has overpainting throughout except for the sitter's head. Plate may have been previously framed as overpainting shows evidence of an oval mat.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from William Reese Co. (Swann Galleries' sale, 2009 February 26, lot 355) on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund, 2009.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Draft, typescript carbon, corrected, of Vidor's screenplay for the film Hallelujah!, with continuity by Wanda Tuchock.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Royal Books on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund, 2016.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: One ALS to "Dear Carlo" from "Edward III" regarding The Clinton News.
Removed from: The Clinton news (New York, N.Y.: Board of Publications of the General Organization of the De Witt Clinton Public High School). Autograph: Countee Cullen.

did.unittitle: Letter : 146 Central Park Avenue West, New York, New York, to Mrs. Whiteson

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Glenn Horowitz Bookseller, Inc., 2011.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: TLS, dated August 7, 1961. Accompanied by printed material: Press release from the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, "Spingarn Medal Goes to James Weldon Johnson" (June 13, 1925), leaflet "Musicraft presents James Weldon Johnson" (August, 1938), leaflet for Musicraft Album No. 21 "James Weldon Johnson, Four Readings from God's Trombones (undated), press release from MacMillan Company of Canada regarding James Weldon Johnson's death (circa June 1938), "The Proposed James Weldon Johnson Memorial" by Carl Van Vechten (February 1940), "James Weldon Johnson: A Biographical Sketch" (Fisk University, circa 1938), and typescript "June 17th is James Weldon Johnson's Birthday!" (after 1938).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Third draft, typescript mimeograph, corrected, of Weller's screenplay for the film Ragtime . Stapled in is a typed letter, signed, from J. Blake Lowe, Jr. to Kellam de Forest on Dino Le Laurentiis Company letterhead, dated 1980 April 25. Copy likely belonged to uncredited pre-production assistant, "Mrs. Boriskin," with her name in holograph pencil on the title page.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Royal Books on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund, 2015.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Seven TLS from Bontemps to Wesley (of the Moorland Foundation at the Howard University Library in Washington, D.C.) and four TLC of Wesley's responses. Correspondence pertains to proposed "Poets' Festival" at Howard University.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Seven TLS from Hughes to Wesley and four TLC of Wesley's replies. Correspondence largely pertains to a proposed "Poets' Festival" at Howard University. Also includes typescript, signed and inscribed to Wesley, of Hughes's poem "The Backlash Blues" and a newspaper clipping about Hughes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: AN on N.A.A.C.P. letterhead, possibly in hand of Walter White and relating to Rudolph Fisher's The Walls of Jericho.
Removed from The Walls of Jericho (New York: A.A. Knopf, 1928).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two TLS and one business card (for Salem Tutt Whitney). The letters offer advice and encouragement to Woodson and are written on letterhead for The Florence Mills Theatrical Association, Inc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Draft, typescript photocopy, corrected, of Wilson's script for the play Jitney . Includes a playbill from the 2000 May revival at the Penumbra Theatre in St. Paul, Minnesota.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Royal Books on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund, 2015.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Draft, typescript, of unpublished short story. Inscription on cover: "Unpublished--sent to Constance Webb by Richard Wright."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Typescript, signed, responses to three questions regarding "Human Intelligence" written in an unidentified hand at the top of the manuscript. The three questions are: 1. Is human intelligence a unity, i.e./a complete whole in itself; 2. Is it possible for a man of genius to be as prominent in one disciplines as in another?; 3. Could a famous scientist who concentrates in a definite kind of research (or a famous writer who specializes in a certain type of literature), apply his intelligence to any field he would choose, successfully?

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from David Schulson Autographs on the James Weldon Johnson Memorial Collection of Negro Arts & Letters Fund, 2012.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed, to Henri Corbiere. The letter contains answers to questions about Wright's literary life posed by Corbiere. Corbiere's questions are written in his hand at the top of the page.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Schulson Autographs on the Sinclair Lewis Fund, 2016.
